page.title: 05WINTERINGHAM TOPOGRAPHY
page.content: The village of Winteringham is situa- ted at the northern end of the lime- stone ridge, Lincoln Edge, where the escarpment decends northwards to the Humber. The village faces the Humber across which are magnificent views of the Yorkshire Wolds, and, to the east the span of the Humber Bridge. For centuries the village looked to the Humber for its livelihood in commerce and fishing. The Humber is now only used from Winteringham for recreation. About 40% of the parish stands on the limestone and is quick draining, the remainder is reclaimed marshland cut by drains. A high embankment on the riverside, and sluices in the drains, prevents access of salt river water to the land. The eastern part of the village is in the Ancolme valley across which can be seen the Lincoln Wolds.
